quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Kinematics on Inclined Surfaces
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2 Quiz 4: Motion on Inclined Planes (10 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A skier starts from rest at the top of a $20^{\circ}$ slope and accelerates uniformly down the incline. If she reaches a speed of $15 \text{ m/s}$ after traveling $40 \text{ m}$ down the slope, what is her acceleration? (Assume no friction)

A block is projected up a $25^{\circ}$ incline with an initial speed of $8.0 \text{ m/s}$. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_k = 0.20$. How far up the incline does it travel before coming to rest?
questions.explanation: Acceleration up incline: $a = -g(\sin\theta + \mu_k\cos\theta) = -9.8(0.4226 + 0.1813) = -5.918 \text{ m/s}^2$. Distance: $0 = 8.0^2 + 2(-5.918)d \Rightarrow d = 64/11.836 \approx 5.41 \text{ m}$.

questions.question: A box slides down a $30^{\circ}$ incline from rest. If it takes $4.0 \text{ s}$ to reach the bottom, what is the length of the incline? (Assume no friction)
A car coasts up a $10^{\circ}$ hill with an initial speed of $20 \text{ m/s}$. Ignoring friction and air resistance, how far up the hill does it travel before stopping?
A snowboarder starts from rest at the top of a $35^{\circ}$ slope that is $50 \text{ m}$ long. If there's no friction, what is his speed at the bottom?
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = g\sin\theta = 5.621 \text{ m/s}^2$. Speed: $v^2 = 0 + 2 \times 5.621 \times 50 = 562.1 \Rightarrow v \approx 23.7 \text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A block is given an initial push up a $40^{\circ}$ incline with speed $6.0 \text{ m/s}$. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_k = 0.30$. How long does it take to return to its starting point?
questions.explanation: Up: $a_{\text{up}} = -g(\sin\theta + \mu_k\cos\theta) = -8.551 \text{ m/s}^2$, $t_{\text{up}} \approx 0.7015 \text{ s}$, $d \approx 2.105 \text{ m}$. Down: $a_{\text{down}} = g(\sin\theta - \mu_k\cos\theta) = 4.047 \text{ m/s}^2$, $t_{\text{down}} \approx 1.020 \text{ s}$. Total $\approx 1.72 \text{ s}$.

questions.question: A ball is rolled up a $15^{\circ}$ incline with an initial speed of $12 \text{ m/s}$. How much time elapses before it returns to its starting point? (Assume no friction)
questions.explanation: Acceleration magnitude $a = g\sin\theta = 2.536 \text{ m/s}^2$. Time up: $t_{\text{up}} = 12/2.536 \approx 4.731 \text{ s}$. Total time $= 2 \times t_{\text{up}} \approx 9.46 \text{ s}$.

questions.question: A crate slides down a $28^{\circ}$ incline starting from rest. If the incline is $12 \text{ m}$ long and it takes $3.5 \text{ s}$ to reach the bottom, what is the coefficient of kinetic friction?
questions.explanation: First find acceleration: $12 = 0.5 \times a \times (3.5)^2 \Rightarrow a \approx 1.959 \text{ m/s}^2$. Then $1.959 = 9.8(\sin 28^{\circ} - \mu_k\cos 28^{\circ}) \Rightarrow \mu_k \approx 0.305$.

questions.question: A skateboarder rolls down a $22^{\circ}$ ramp that is $8.0 \text{ m}$ long. If he starts from rest and there's no friction, what is his speed at the bottom?
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = g\sin\theta = 3.671 \text{ m/s}^2$. Speed: $v^2 = 0 + 2 \times 3.671 \times 8.0 = 58.736 \Rightarrow v \approx 7.66 \text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A block is projected up a $32^{\circ}$ incline with speed $10 \text{ m/s}$. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_k = 0.25$. What is its speed when it returns to the starting point?
questions.explanation: Up: $a_{\text{up}} = -g(\sin\theta + \mu_k\cos\theta) \approx -7.271 \text{ m/s}^2$, distance $\approx 6.877 \text{ m}$. Down: $a_{\text{down}} = g(\sin\theta - \mu_k\cos\theta) \approx 3.115 \text{ m/s}^2$, $v^2 = 2 \times 3.115 \times 6.877 \approx 42.84 \Rightarrow v \approx 6.55 \text{ m/s}$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered kinematics on inclined surfaces with and without friction.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of inclined plane motion and energy considerations.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Practice distinguishing between frictionless and frictional cases.
scoreMessages.0: Review kinematics equations and force components on inclines.
